question: What is the form of government of the United States?
What is the supreme law of the land? *
Name one thing the U.S. Constitution does.

choices: Protects the rights of the people

question: The U.S. Constitution starts with the words “We the People.” What does “We the People” mean?
distractors: Courts interpret the will of the people

question: How are changes made to the U.S. Constitution?
What does the Bill of Rights protect?

choices: (The basic) rights of people living in the United States

question: How many amendments does the U.S. Constitution have? *
Why is the Declaration of Independence important?

choices: It says America is free from British control.
It says all people are created equal.

distractors: It set up the court system
It created the Bill of Rights
It gave women the right to vote

question: What founding document said the American colonies were free from Britain?
Name two important ideas from the Declaration of Independence and the U.S. Constitution.
The words “Life, Liberty, and the pursuit of Happiness” are in what founding document?
What is the economic system of the United States? *
What is the rule of law?

choices: No one is above the law.

distractors: Wealthy citizens are exempt from law

question: Many documents influenced the U.S. Constitution. Name one.
There are three branches of government. Why?

choices: So one part does not become too powerful

question: Name the three branches of government.
The President of the United States is in charge of which branch of government?
What part of the federal government writes laws?
distractors: The Speaker of the House alone

question: What are the two parts of the U.S. Congress?
Name one power of the U.S. Congress. *
How many U.S. senators are there?
How long is a term for a U.S. senator?
Who is one of your state’s U.S. senators now?
How many voting members are in the House of Representatives?
How long is a term for a member of the House of Representatives?
Why do U.S. representatives serve shorter terms than U.S. senators?

choices: To more closely follow public opinion

distractors: Because there are more of them
To allow more people to serve
Because the House is less important
To balance power with the Senate

question: How many senators does each state have?
Why does each state have two senators?
Name your U.S. representative.
What is the name of the Speaker of the House of Representatives now? *
Who does a U.S. senator represent?
distractors: Only citizens who agree with them
Only military personnel in their state

question: Who elects U.S. senators?
Who does a member of the House of Representatives represent?
distractors: Only citizens who voted for them

question: Who elects members of the House of Representatives?
Some states have more representatives than other states. Why?
distractors: (Because of) their age as a state

question: The President of the United States is elected for how many years? *
The President of the United States can serve only two terms. Why?

choices: To keep the president from becoming too powerful

distractors: To allow new ideas in government
Because the Constitution originally limited it
To give more people a chance to serve

question: What is the name of the President of the United States now? *
What is the name of the Vice President of the United States now? *
If the president can no longer serve, who becomes president?

choices: The Vice President (of the United States)

question: Name one power of the president.
Who is Commander in Chief of the U.S. military?
distractors: The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs

question: Who signs bills to become laws?
Who vetoes bills? *
Who appoints federal judges?
The executive branch has many parts. Name one.
What does the President’s Cabinet do?

choices: Advises the President (of the United States)

question: What are two Cabinet-level positions?

choices: Secretary of Health and Human Services
Secretary of Housing and Urban Development
Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency
Administrator of the Small Business Administration
Director of the Central Intelligence Agency
Director of the Office of Management and Budget

question: Why is the Electoral College important?

choices: It decides who is elected president.
It provides a compromise between the popular election of the president and congressional selection.

distractors: It speeds up the election process
It gives every citizen an equal vote
It follows the will of the majority directly
It gives larger states more power
It eliminates the need for primaries
It honors the founding fathers' wishes only
It gives Congress the final say
It balances state and federal power only
It eliminates the need for campaigning

question: What is one part of the judicial branch?
What does the judicial branch do?

choices: Decides if a law goes against the (U.S.) Constitution

question: What is the highest court in the United States? *
How many seats are on the Supreme Court?
distractors: Set by the Constitution at twelve

question: How many Supreme Court justices are usually needed to decide a case?
How long do Supreme Court justices serve?
Supreme Court justices serve for life. Why?
distractors: To reduce the need for elections

question: Who is the Chief Justice of the United States now?
Name one power that is only for the federal government.
Name one power that is only for the states.
What is the purpose of the 10th Amendment?

choices: (It states that the) powers not given to the federal government belong to the states or to the people.

distractors: (It) creates the three branches of government
(It) gives all power to the federal government
(It) gives women the right to vote

question: Who is the governor of your state now? *

choices.governor: D.C. does not have a Governor, but the Mayor is Muriel Bowser

question: What is the capital of your state?

choices.capital: D.C. is not a state and does not have a capital

question: There are four amendments to the U.S. Constitution about who can vote. Describe one of them.

choices: You don’t have to pay (a poll tax) to vote.
Any citizen can vote. (Women and men can vote.)
A male citizen of any race (can vote).

distractors: Citizens must pass a literacy test
Voting is mandatory for all citizens
Citizens must own land to vote

question: Who can vote in federal elections, run for federal office, and serve on a jury in the United States?
What are three rights of everyone living in the United States?
distractors: Right to vote in federal elections

question: What do we show loyalty to when we say the Pledge of Allegiance? *
Name two promises that new citizens make in the Oath of Allegiance.

choices: Give up loyalty to other countries
Obey the laws of the United States
Serve (help, do important work for) the nation (if needed)
Be loyal to the United States

question: How can people become United States citizens?

choices: Be born in the United States, under the conditions set by the 14th Amendment
Derive citizenship (under conditions set by Congress)

distractors: Live in the U.S. for 10 years
Have a job in the U.S.

question: What are two examples of civic participation in the United States?

choices: Give an elected official your opinion (on an issue)
Support or oppose an issue or policy

question: What is one way Americans can serve their country?

choices: Work for local, state, or federal government

question: Why is it important to pay federal taxes?

choices: All people pay to fund the federal government

distractors: It pays for local schools only
It pays off the national debt only
States decide how to use it
It funds the President's salary only

question: It is important for all men age 18 through 25 to register for the Selective Service. Name one reason why.

choices: Makes the draft fair, if needed

distractors: It helps the government track citizens
It's required for a driver's license
It's required for federal employment only

question: The colonists came to America for many reasons. Name one.
Who lived in America before the Europeans arrived? *
What group of people was taken and sold as slaves?
What war did the Americans fight to win independence from Britain?
Name one reason why the Americans declared independence from Britain.

choices: British soldiers stayed in Americans’ houses (boarding, quartering)

question: Who wrote the Declaration of Independence? *
When was the Declaration of Independence adopted?
The American Revolution had many important events. Name one.

choices: Washington Crossing the Delaware (Battle of Trenton)

question: There were 13 original states. Name five.
What founding document was written in 1787?
The Federalist Papers supported the passage of the U.S. Constitution. Name one of the writers.
Why were the Federalist Papers important?

choices: They helped people understand the (U.S.) Constitution.

distractors: They created the Bill of Rights
They negotiated the Treaty of Paris

question: Benjamin Franklin is famous for many things. Name one.

choices: Founded the first free public libraries
First Postmaster General of the United States
Helped write the Declaration of Independence

distractors: First Chief Justice of the Supreme Court
Writer of the Federalist Papers alone
Third president of the United States
Author of the Virginia Declaration of Rights
First president of the United States

question: George Washington is famous for many things. Name one. *

choices: First president of the United States

distractors: Writer of the Declaration of Independence
Writer of the Federalist Papers alone
First Chief Justice of the Supreme Court
Author of the Bill of Rights alone
Fourth president of the United States
First Vice President of the United States

question: Thomas Jefferson is famous for many things. Name one.

choices: Writer of the Declaration of Independence
Third president of the United States
Doubled the size of the United States (Louisiana Purchase)
Writer of the Virginia Statute on Religious Freedom

distractors: Author of the Federalist Papers alone
First Vice President of the United States
Negotiated the Treaty of Paris alone
First Chief Justice of the Supreme Court
Established the First Bank of the United States
First president of the United States

question: James Madison is famous for many things. Name one.

choices: Fourth president of the United States
One of the writers of the Federalist Papers

distractors: Writer of the Declaration of Independence
First Chief Justice of the Supreme Court
Established the First Bank of the United States
First president of the United States
Third president of the United States
First Vice President of the United States

question: Alexander Hamilton is famous for many things. Name one.

choices: One of the writers of the Federalist Papers
Helped establish the First Bank of the United States

distractors: First president of the United States
Third president of the United States
Writer of the Declaration of Independence
First Vice President of the United States
Fourth president of the United States
First Chief Justice of the Supreme Court
Led troops at the Battle of Bunker Hill

question: What territory did the United States buy from France in 1803?

Name the U.S. war between the North and the South.
The Civil War had many important events. Name one.

choices: Led the United States during the Civil War

question: What did the Emancipation Proclamation do?

choices: Freed slaves in the Confederate states
Freed slaves in most Southern states

distractors: Gave women the right to vote

question: What U.S. war ended slavery?
What amendment says all persons born or naturalized in the United States, and subject to the jurisdiction thereof, are U.S. citizens?
When did all men get the right to vote?
distractors: At the founding of the nation

question: Why did the United States enter World War I?

choices: To support the Allied Powers (England, France, Italy, and Russia)
To oppose the Central Powers (Germany, Austria-Hungary, the Ottoman Empire, and Bulgaria)

distractors: To liberate Europe from Nazi Germany
Because of the assassination of an American leader
Because of a direct attack on U.S. soil
To honor a treaty with Britain
Because of the sinking of the Titanic

section: Recent American History and Other Important Historical Information
question: When did all women get the right to vote?
distractors: At the founding of the nation

choices: Longest economic recession in modern history

question: Why did the United States enter World War II?

choices: To support the Allied Powers (England, France, and Russia)
To oppose the Axis Powers (Germany, Italy, and Japan)

distractors: Because of the assassination of a leader

question: Dwight Eisenhower is famous for many things. Name one.

choices: President at the end of (during) the Korean War

distractors: Led the D-Day invasion of Japan

distractors: Because of a treaty obligation alone

choices: Worked for equality for all Americans
Worked to ensure that people would “not be judged by the color of their skin, but by the content

question: Why did the United States enter the Persian Gulf War?

choices: To force the Iraqi military from Kuwait

distractors: To find weapons of mass destruction

question: Name one example of an American innovation.
What is the capital of the United States?
Where is the Statue of Liberty?

choices: Liberty Island [Also acceptable are New Jersey, near New York City, and on the Hudson (River).]

question: Why does the flag have 13 stripes? *

choices: (Because the stripes) represent the original colonies

distractors: For the 13 amendments in the Bill of Rights
For the 13 signers of the Declaration
For the 13 original states after the Constitution
For the 13 battles of the Revolution
For the 13 months of the year
For the 13 stars on the original flag

question: Why does the flag have 50 stars?

choices: (Because there is) one star for each state

distractors: For the 50 signers of the Constitution

question: What is the name of the national anthem?
distractors: The Battle Hymn of the Republic
Columbia, the Gem of the Ocean
The Proud to Be an American

question: The Nation’s first motto was “E Pluribus Unum.” What does that mean?
distractors: One for all, all for one

question: What is Independence Day?

choices: A holiday to celebrate U.S. independence (from Britain)

distractors: The day the Constitution was signed
The day the Revolutionary War ended
The day George Washington became President
The day the Bill of Rights was ratified
The day women got the right to vote
The day the flag was created
The day the last British troops left

question: Name three national U.S. holidays. *

choices: A holiday to honor soldiers who died in military service

distractors: A holiday to honor all living veterans
A holiday to honor the President
A holiday celebrating the end of World War II
A holiday to remember Pearl Harbor
A holiday to honor police officers
A holiday for all government workers
A holiday to honor the founding fathers
A holiday to honor civil rights leaders

question: What is Veterans Day?

choices: A holiday to honor people in the (U.S.) military
A holiday to honor people who have served (in the U.S. military)

distractors: A holiday to celebrate the end of World War I
A holiday to remember Pearl Harbor
A holiday to honor the founding fathers
A holiday to honor civil rights leaders
A holiday to honor soldiers who died
A holiday to honor the President
A holiday to honor police officers
A holiday to honor government workers
